content.content: Most writers follow the subject-verb-object sentence structure. Example: My grandmother came into the kitchen In an inverted sentence, the order is reversed so that the subject follows the verb. Example: Into the kitchen came my grandmother.
content.htmlContent: Most writers follow the subject-verb-object sentence structure. Example: My grandmother came into the kitchen In an inverted sentence, the order is reversed so that the subject follows the verb. Example: Into the kitchen came my grandmother.

content.content: The most common subordinators are: although, even though, because, since, so that, when, while, before, after, whenever, wherever, anywhere, if, unless, whether [or not], as, whereas. Subordinators are words that introduce subordinate or dependent clauses. If a clause begins with a subordinating word, that clause cannot stand alone as a sentence. For example: When I went to the shop yesterday... Although I know him well... These clauses are dependent, and you need to add more information: When I went to the shop yesterday, I met an old friend. Although I know him well, I don't think he'll come.
content.htmlContent: The most common subordinators are: although, even though, because, since, so that, when, while, before, after, whenever, wherever, anywhere, if, unless, whether [or not], as, whereas. Subordinators are words that introduce subordinate or dependent clauses. If a clause begins with a subordinating word, that clause cannot stand alone as a sentence. For example: When I went to the shop yesterday... Although I know him well... These clauses are dependent, and you need to add more information: When I went to the shop yesterday, I met an old friend. Although I know him well, I don't think he'll come.

content.content: The relative pronouns are who, whom, whose, which, and that. Relative pronouns are used to refer to nouns mentioned previously in the sentence, whether they are people, places, things, animals, or ideas. Relative clauses tell us more about people and things, and they can be used to join two clauses into one. Examples: Mary, who is 19, started university this year. This is the house that Jack built. The girl, who solved the task, was praised by the teacher. We use: - who and whom for people - which for things - that for people or things.
content.htmlContent: The relative pronouns are who, whom, whose, which, and that. Relative pronouns are used to refer to nouns mentioned previously in the sentence, whether they are people, places, things, animals, or ideas. Relative clauses tell us more about people and things, and they can be used to join two clauses into one. Examples: Mary, who is 19, started university this year. This is the house that Jack built. The girl, who solved the task, was praised by the teacher. We use: - who and whom for people - which for things - that for people or things.

content.content: Coordinating conjunctions are connecting words that join two similarly constructed and/or syntactically equal words, phrases, or clauses within a sentence. Example: We were out of milk, so I went to the store to buy some. We would love to attend your birthday party, but we have plans that day. The English language has seven coordinating conjunctions: for, and, nor, but, or, yet, and so. A good way to remember the coordinating conjunctions is to use the acronym F.A.N.B.O.Y.S.
content.htmlContent: Coordinating conjunctions are connecting words that join two similarly constructed and/or syntactically equal words, phrases, or clauses within a sentence. Example: We were out of milk, so I went to the store to buy some. We would love to attend your birthday party, but we have plans that day. The English language has seven coordinating conjunctions: for, and, nor, but, or, yet, and so. A good way to remember the coordinating conjunctions is to use the acronym F.A.N.B.O.Y.S.

content.content: The Privy Council of the United Kingdom, officially Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council, is a formal body of advisers to the sovereign of the United Kingdom. Its members are mainly senior politicians who are current or former members of either the House of Commons or the House of Lords.
content.htmlContent: The Privy Council of the United Kingdom, officially Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council, is a formal body of advisers to the sovereign of the United Kingdom. Its members are mainly senior politicians who are current or former members of either the House of Commons or the House of Lords.

metaImage.alt: Painting: Impressionist painting of the UK Parliament building. Painted by Claude Monet.

content.content: An electoral precinct is the smallest unit into which electoral districts are divided. Each precinct has a specific polling station where its residents go to vote. However, more than one precinct may use the same polling station.
content.htmlContent: An electoral precinct is the smallest unit into which electoral districts are divided. Each precinct has a specific polling station where its residents go to vote. However, more than one precinct may use the same polling station.

content.content: A Chinese box is a box inside a box, like a Russian Matryoshka doll. In literature, 'a Chinese box structure' means that the literary work has a frame narrative, a novel or drama that is told in the form of a narrative inside a narrative (and so on), giving views from different perspectives. Examples include Plato's dialogue Symposion, Mary Shelley's 1818 novel Frankenstein, Jostein Gaarder's The Solitaire Mystery, Emily Brontë's Wuthering Heights, and Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness.

content.content: The Philippine–American War, previously referred to as the Philippine Insurrection or the Tagalog Insurgency by the United States, was an armed conflict between the First Philippine Republic and the United States that lasted from 4 February, 1899, to 2 July, 1902. The Philippines passed from Spain to The United States in the Treaty of Paris of 1898, which ended the Spanish–American war. Philippine freedom fighters refused to accept US dominance. The war became bloody, with atrocities committed by both sides. At least 200 000 civilians died because of the conflict.

The war became bloody, with atrocities committed by both sides. At least 200 000 civilians died because of the conflict.

content.content: The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is a novella by Robert Louis Stevenson, first published in 1886. Mr Hyde, a hideous, violent man, comes to the attention of some gentlemen after he attacks a woman. The men demand that he pay the woman restitution, and he brings them to a back door and asks them to wait. He comes back with a cheque signed by Dr Jekyll. The men become curious about the relationship between the respectable doctor and the violent man, and worry he may be being blackmailed. The reality is far more sinister. Stevenson's story has been turned into plays and films and has inspired countless other authors to explore similar subjects.

Mr Hyde, a hideous, violent man, comes to the attention of some gentlemen after he attacks a woman. The men demand that he pay the woman restitution, and he brings them to a back door and asks them to wait. He comes back with a cheque signed by Dr Jekyll. The men become curious about the relationship between the respectable doctor and the violent man, and worry he may be being blackmailed. The reality is far more sinister. Stevenson's story has been turned into plays and films and has inspired countless other authors to explore similar subjects.

Two well dressed men are facing each other in an old-fashioned study at night. The man on the left looks stunned, and is holding up his arms as if to protect himself. A ghostly, ugly man is protruding from the bottom half of the man on the right." data-caption="The transformation" data-url="https://api.test.ndla.no/image-api/v2/images/59180"></ndlaembed>

content.content: Jacobean drama is a term that describes the plays written during the reign of James 1 (1603–1625). In the beginning of the period, plays were very similar to those of the preceding Elizabethan period, but over time satire became the dominant genre, and many plays focused on corruption. Plays about vengeance also became popular during the Jacobean period. While usually considered an Elizabethan playwright, many of Shakespeare's most popular plays were written during the Jacobean period. Other famous playwrights of the period are Ben Johnson and John Webster.

In the beginning of the period, plays were very similar to those of the preceding Elizabethan period, but over time satire became the dominant genre, and many plays focused on corruption. Plays about vengeance also became popular during the Jacobean period. While usually considered an Elizabethan playwright, many of Shakespeare's most popular plays were written during the Jacobean period. Other famous playwrights of the period are Ben Johnson and John Webster.
